#Text=Exclusive : David Anderson talks about the Stardust@home project
#Text=Tuesday , January 24 , 2006

#Text=Following the return of the Stardust space capsule from its encounter with the Comet Wild 2 , NASA scientists have come up with a novel approach to dealing with the samples of " interstellar dust " that have been collected ; they want help from the public .

column1: #Text=The Stardust spacecraft carried an aerogel -based dust collector , which was exposed to space in varying orientations during different phases of the mission .

#Text=Only one side of the collector was exposed towards the stream of particles coming off the Comet Wild 2 during the encounter in 2004 , while the other side was used to collect interstellar dust at an earlier point in the spacecraft 's journey .

#Text=Although scientists have seen the particles captured from comet Wild 2 when they examined the aerogel , they have not examined any of the particles expected on the other side of the collector due to their smallness .
#Text=They will be examined after they are found with the help of Stardust@home .
#Text=It is believed that on the order of 50 interstellar dust particles impacted the aerogel , each now resting inside a tiny crater .
#Text=Stardust traveled nearly three billion miles and its mission lasted seven years .
#Text=At times it was traveling at 8 miles a second .
#Text=Thats fast enough to go from San Francisco to Los Angeles in one minute .

#Text=Stardust set a new all-time record for being the fastest spacecraft to return to Earth , breaking the previous record set in May of 1969 during the return of the Apollo X ( 10 ) command module .
#Text=Don Brownlee of the University of Washington , Seattle said " our spacecraft has traveled further than anything from Earth ever has – and came back .

#Text=I was wondering If I could get some questions answered or if you could give me some  insider " info for the project .

column1: #Text=I am aware that you are taking place in the development of the VM ( Virtual Microscope ) ...
#Text=Could I know more about that ?
#Text=The ' virtual microscope ' lets you scan through a set of images as if you were turning the focus knob on a microscope .
#Text=The images are fairly large ( about 100 KB each ) so it 's important to pre-load the images .
#Text=While you 're looking through one set of images , the VM is busy downloading the JPEG files for the next set .
#Text=David P. Anderson , one of the creaters of Stardust@home 's Virtual Microscope and Director of SETI@home .
#Text=At first we thought we 'd have to do this with a Java applet or Flash program - something tricky and complicated .
#Text=My contribution was to point out that it could be done fairly easily using Javascript , and I wrote a prototype of this .
#Text=Will this project use the BOINC Platform/Program ?
#Text=No. We thought about using some parts of BOINC ( like the database and web pages for creating " accounts " ) but it was easier just to do this from scratch .
#Text=How long will the project take ?
#Text=It depends how many volunteers participate , and how fast they look at the ' focus movies ' .
#Text=It will probably be just a month or two .
#Text=Anyone can join but they have to take a test before they can participate .
#Text=What will the test include ?
#Text=Looking at some focus movies and deciding whether they contain a dust particle .
#Text=Participants see a lot of training examples before they take the test .
#Text=It 's easy , not like a test in school .
#Text=How many will be allowed to participate ?
#Text=No limit as of now .
#Text=When will the project start ?
#Text=I think in about 2 months .
#Text=It will take that long to transport the aerogel to the laboratory , and photograph it with the microscope .
#Text=The software is ready to go .
#Text=Will the VM project analyze any of the particles or just look for them ?
#Text=Stardust@home will only locate the particles .
#Text=When they are located , they will be cut out of the aerogel and physically analyzed .
#Text=Thank you for your time David .
#Text=And great work on the upcoming project and SETI@home .
